newsitem.title: USA: U.S. heat wave pushes up power demand, pollution.
newsitem.headline: U.S. heat wave pushes up power demand, pollution.

text.p: An oppressive heat wave smothering the populous Northeast is breaking records for electricity demand and straining the multistate power grid.
It is also pumping up air pollution levels, as utilities turn to old coal and oil-burning power plants in a bid to keep pace with demand from millions of air conditioners.

"Our forecast is that we will exceed yesterday's load," Richard Mulieri, a spokesman for Consolidated Edison in New York City, said Wednesday. "As the day goes on, we'll have a better idea where we end up."

ConEd hit a record power load of 11,013 megawatts (MW) late Tuesday when the thermometer in Central Park hit a withering 97 degrees. This easily surpassed the previous record of 10,805 MW on Aug. 2, 1995.
But the record was marred by outages in some of the city's northern suburbs and an 8 percent voltage reduction, or "brownout," in parts of the New York City borough of Brooklyn.

ConEd warned again Wednesday that power demand could hit a new high and urged customers in some neighbourhoods to switch off all unnecessary lights and appliances, especially energy-hungry air conditioners.
The warning was repeated across much of the East Coast.

The New England Power Pool, which oversees operation of the power grid spanning the region's six states, declared Wednesday a "conservation day" and asked customers to voluntarily cut back on electricity usage.

Grid operators in the Mid-Atlantic states told their member utilities to issue the same plea after PJM, the Pennsylvania-New Jersey-Maryland Interconnection, reported it moved a record 49,820 MW of power Tuesday.
PJM oversees the operation of 540 power plants and transmission lines serving about 9.1 million customers from northern New Jersey to Maryland, including Baltimore and Philadelphia.
Temperatures across the Mid-Atlantic states are expected to hit the 90s again Wednesday, the fifth day of 90-plus weather in what is so far the summer's most severe heat wave.
To cope with the surging electrical loads, many utilities are firing up older, less efficient coal- and oil-burning power plants, many dating from the 1950s.
While automobiles account for most low-level ozone, fossil fuel power plants are also major contributors.

"It is an unfortunate coincidence that hot weather results in higher power generation for cooling and also in a rise in ozone levels. ... It's kind of a double whammy," said Marika Tatsutani, a policy analyst at the Boston-based Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management.
She said the problem was compounded by high electricity demand in the Ohio Valley, where generating units are currently running flat out.
Most big Midwest power stations are coal-fired, and the nitrogen oxides they emit tend to drift eastward on the prevailing winds.

"Power plants are particularly good at contributing to the transported pollution problem because they have very tall smokestacks, which is an old-fashioned solution to the problem -- just send it higher into the air," she said.
